head.title: The New Look of the Senate Race

hedline.hl1: The New Look of the Senate Race

abstract.p: Prof Robert Dallek letter on Rick Lazio's attack on 'liberal' ideas; asks whether he refers to FDA, FTC, Social Security orother 'failures'(S)

block.p: In announcing his candidacy for senator from New York, Representative Rick Lazio decried ''the liberal ideas that so painfully failed us in the last century'' (front page, May 21). True, progressivism under Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson and liberalism under Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson had their limitations, but their successes far outran their missteps.

In announcing his candidacy for senator from New York, Representative Rick Lazio decried ''the liberal ideas that so painfully failed us in the last century'' (front page, May 21). True, progressivism under Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson and liberalism under Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson had their limitations, but their successes far outran their missteps.

Is Mr. Lazio opposed to Theodore Roosevelt's Food and Drug Administration and conservation initiatives? To Wilson's Federal Reserve and Federal Trade Commission reforms? To F.D.R.'s Tennessee Valley Authority, Social Security, Securities and Exchange Commission and minimum wage laws? Or to Kennedy's and Johnson's civil rights, voting rights, aid to education and Medicare statutes?
The writer is a professor of history at Boston University.
